title: The Bridge Concept üåâ
ques: React Native uses JavaScript to control native iOS/Android components. How does the JS talk to the Native side? Explain the **Bridge**.

answer.content:
The **Bridge** allows asynchronous communication. 
JavaScript sends JSON messages across the bridge (serialized). The Native side receives them and performs the UI update (e.g., "Draw a Button at x:10, y:20"). 
(Note: The new Fabric architecture removes the bridge for C++ bindings).

explanation: This allows you to write JS but get real Native UI, not a Web View.

title: View System üñºÔ∏è
ques: In React Native, you use `<View>` and `<Text>` instead of `<div>` and `<span>`. Why?

answer.content:
Because `<div>` is an HTML concept. 
Android/iOS don't understand HTML. `<View>` is an abstraction that maps to `UIView` on iOS and `android.view.View` on Android. React Native compiles these abstractions to their platform-specific native equivalents.

title: Styling: Flexbox üì¶
ques: React Native uses a subset of CSS. What is the primary layout engine used?

answer.content:
**Flexbox** (via the Yoga engine). 
It works almost exactly like CSS Flexbox (defaulting to `flex-direction: column`). It ensures layouts scale correctly across different screen densities and sizes without hardcoded pixels.

explanation: If you know Web CSS Flexbox, you know React Native layout.

title: Native Modules üîå
ques: What is a **Native Module**? When would you need to write one?

answer.content:
A Native Module is custom Java/Swift code that exposes a native platform API to JavaScript. 
You write one when React Native doesn't support a specific feature out of the box (e.g., a specific payment SDK or image processing library).

explanation: This is the escape hatch. You are never limited by JS; you can always drop down to native code.

title: Hot Reloading üî•
ques: How does **Fast Refresh** (Hot Reloading) improve the mobile development experience compared to traditional Native dev?

answer.content:
In traditional native (Swift/Java), you must re-compile the app for every change (taking 1-5 minutes). 
In React Native, JS changes are injected instantly (sub-second) into the running app without losing state, mimicking the web dev speed.

explanation: This rapid feedback loop is React Native's biggest selling point.
